I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  This is a proposal for technical assistance (TA) to support capacity building in the 
pensions industries of developing member countries (DMCs). The proposed program aims to 
deepen the understanding of pension fund professionals in DMCs of international trends and 
best practice in sustainable and responsible investment (SRI)1 and governance practices. The 
program will draw on the experiences of the pensions industries in more developed countries in 
Asia and elsewhere to provide training for professionals in the region. It will also seek to 
encourage  interaction  between  these  countries  and  DMCs,  both  among  (i)  pensions  and 
investment  professionals,  and  (ii)  relevant  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  and  SRI 
specialists. The focus of the training will be strategies and policies pertaining to SRI, such as 
long-term capital allocation, investment strategy, performance measurement, governance, and 
stakeholder  accountability,  which  will  have  a  substantial  impact  on  standards  of  fiduciary 
behavior in the pensions sector in Asia. The Design and Monitoring Framework for the TA is set 
out in Appendix 1. 
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is planning to engage with the DMCs’ rapidly 
growing pensions sector through a number of TAs, with the overall objective of fostering efficient 
allocation  of  pension  resources  and  building  capacity  to  deploy  resources  responsibly  in 
domestic productive assets.2
 
3.  The TA will complement the activities of recent ADB projects and initiatives which have 
supported reform of social security and pension systems in the region. For example, training 
activities have included an ADB/ADB Institute “Capacity Building Conference on Reforming 
Pension Systems in the Asian Transitional Economies” held in the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC) in 2001, together with the PRC’s Ministry of Labor and Social Security. More recently, 
ADB was a joint organizer in 2004 of the third Conference on Private Pensions in Asia, together 
with  the  Organisation  for  Economic  Co-operation  and  Development  (OECD)  and  the 
International  Network  of  Pension  Regulators  and  Supervisors.  The  proposed  TA  is  also 
complementary  to  two  TAs  that  South  Asia  Governance  and  Finance  Division  (SAGF)  is 
currently implementing in India.3
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Asia is experiencing an enormous demographic shift, with major implications for the 
economies and societies of the region. A United Nations Economic and Social Commission for 
Asia and the Pacific (UNESCAP) study in 2002 stated that the proportion of the population aged 
65 and older is expected to more than double between 1995 and 2050 in almost all countries 
and areas of the UNESCAP region—a process that has taken over a century in OECD countries. 
The United Nations (UN) projects that Asia’s proportion of the world’s population aged 60 and 
older will be 58% in 2050. Declining birth rates mean fewer offspring to provide direct support to 
parents who rely on them for care in their old age. Fewer children will also result in a smaller 
workforce generating lower tax revenues, at a time when the introduction of social security 
schemes may be critically needed. 
 
                                                 
1  SRI is investment that allows investors to take into account wider concerns, such as social justice, economic 
development, peace, or a healthy environment, as well as conventional financial considerations. 
2  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (internet edition) on 22 February 2007. 
3  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance to India for State Level Pension Reform. Manila, and ADB. 2006. Technical 
Assistance to India for Implementing Pension Reforms. Manila.

2   
5.  The PRC and India have by far the highest populations in the region, and some of the 
highest projected numbers of elderly citizens. The UN’s World Population Ageing: 1950–2050 
report estimated that, in 2050, approximately 20% of India’s population and 30% of the PRC’s 
population will be over 60 (by which time the ratio of PRC workers to pensioners is projected to 
decline from 10 to 1 today to about 3 to 1). The governments of both countries have recently 
demonstrated  awareness  of  the  challenges  that  they  face,  and  some  reform  has  been 
undertaken, e.g., introduction of the PRC’s National Social Security Fund. However, pension 
coverage of the population is still extremely low and government policy development is at an 
early stage. 
 
6.  Public spending on pensions in Indonesia and the Philippines in 1993 was less than 1% 
of gross domestic product (GDP)4, but these countries also face aging populations. For example, 
a study carried out by UNESCAP found that the number of Indonesians aged over 65 was just 
3.3% of the total population in 1980, but they accounted for 7.6% by 2000. In Vietnam, a new 
pension  scheme  was  implemented  in  1995,  but  coverage  of  the  working  population  was 
estimated at only 12% in 2000. 
 
7.  Pension systems in most DMCs still have limited coverage and an inflexible structure of 
statutory retirement payments. Many systems suffer from high rates of system evasion and low 
rates of active participation. At the same time, many public pension systems in the region have 
significant liabilities and face serious future funding problems, which were exacerbated by 
financial turmoil in 1997/98. One of the most extreme situations is in the PRC, where the legacy 
of state-owned industries leaves the government with a massive pension liability, which is 
seriously underfunded. The World Bank estimates that the unfunded pension liabilities for the 
urban population are about $900 billion or 75% of the PRC’s GDP. Equally, new findings 
released by New Delhi-based Invest India Economic Foundation show a funding gap for state 
and central government employees in India of 56% of GDP. 
 
8.  Given  this  level  of  underfunding  in  public  pension  systems  across  Asia,  and  the 
demographic  and  social  changes  taking  place  in  the  region,  it  is  essential  that  pension 
authorities and managers in the region are kept informed of all developments in the global 
pensions industry, including governance standards and sustainable investment practices, which 
have an impact on their ability to meet fiduciary responsibilities and maximize long-term income 
generation.   
 
9.  Key  issues  with  regard  to  sustainable  investment  and  governance  that  have  been 
identified as critical for the pensions industry globally include the following. 
(i)  Governance  mechanisms  for  public  pension  funds,  including  examination  of 
government’s role as the sponsor/lead trustee and potential conflicts of interest 
between governments orchestrating privatization and encouraging arm’s length 
oversight of pension funds. 
(ii)  Mechanisms  for  establishing  consensus  on  sustainability  factors  underlying 
policy development. 
(iii)  Pension fund structure design based on a diverse, “multi-pillar” framework (as 
laid out by the World Bank), incorporating mandatory, voluntary, and informal 
elements. 
(iv)  Investment policies that reflect truly long-term risks and opportunities, including 
sustainability factors such as climate change. 
                                                 
4 International Labour Organization. 2001. Social security: A new consensus. Geneva.

3
(v)  Policies with regard to investment in overseas assets. 
(vi)  Procedures for keeping fund beneficiaries informed about investment policies 
and performance. 
(vii)  Appropriate governance and performance benchmarks for community investment 
programs and other alternative investments.  
 
10.  Despite the high relevance of sustainability issues to retirement schemes in Asia, there 
has been little discussion of them in the region. Many pension fund regulators, trustees, and 
officers  are  not  aware  of  sustainable  investment  and  governance  issues,  or  strategies  for 
incorporating SRI elements into their own practices, and are not being updated on global trends. 
Equally, professional advisers to the pensions industry in Asia have not generally been active to 
date in providing information on these issues, despite the fact that a survey of investment 
managers by Mercer Investment Consulting Inc. in 2004 demonstrated that over 85% of Asian 
and Australian managers believed that the adoption of SRI practices and strategies will become 
commonplace within the next 10 years. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The overall goal of the TA is to support capacity building in the pensions industries of 
DMCs. The focus of the TA is the development of best governance and sustainable investment 
practices in the pensions industry of DMCs, with the goal of optimizing investment performance 
and standards of fiduciary responsibility.   
 
12.  The TA is structured to cover five DMCs that face some of the greatest challenges in the 
region:  PRC  and  India  by  virtue  of  the  size  of  their  elderly  populations;  and  Indonesia, 
Philippines, and Viet Nam—representing DMCs that have made very little progress to date 
toward reform of their pensions systems. 
 
13.  In all these countries, pensions policy is at an early stage of development and there is a 
lack of sophistication among practitioners. Pension fund regulators, trustees, and officers in 
these  countries  would  greatly  benefit  from  information  about  developments  in  the  global 
pensions industry, including sustainable investment practices and governance standards, which 
may have an impact on their ability to meet fiduciary responsibilities and maximize long-term 
income generation. 
 
14.  The objectives of the TA in the pensions industry will be to do the following. 
(i)  Increase  understanding  of  the  importance  of  SRI  and  optimizing  fiduciary 
behavior in the pensions industry in DMCs. 
(ii)  Create  greater  awareness  in  DMCs  of  the  relationship  between  pensions 
strategy and national social and environmental constraints. 
(iii)  Increase knowledge in the pensions industry in DMCs of global and regional 
developments in SRI and governance, and examples of best practice. 
(iv)  Improve  understanding  in  the  pensions  industry  in  DMCs  of  SRI  products, 
metrics, and performance characteristics. 
(v)  Provide pensions professionals (officers, trustees, advisers, and regulators) in 
DMCs  with  the  technical  and  operational  skills  required  for  execution  of 
governance and sustainable investment policies to international standards.

4   
(vi)  Encourage dialogue between pensions professionals and NGOs, government, 
and business in DMCs on further development of sustainable investment in the 
region. 
(vii)  Contribute to ADB's continuing efforts for supporting development of DMCs’ long-
term capital markets, which can mitigate the mismatch of maturities. 
 
15.  This  TA  is  designed  to  form  the  first  stage  in  a  program  that  is  intended  to  be 
(i) educational; and (ii) diagnostic, with the long-term aim of identifying the most appropriate 
educational tools for a wide range of policy needs in DMCs in order to present the best of global 
SRI  practices  in  a  framework  that  is  accessible  to  pensions  professionals  and  interested 
stakeholders.    
 
16.  The TA will deliver a number of direct outputs, but also intends to create an ongoing 
process  of  information  sharing  and  discussion  within  the  pensions  industry  in  the  region. 
Specifically, this TA will target a number of rapidly changing DMCs in SRI training program for 
pension professionals (pensions officers, trustees, and regulators) covering China, People’s 
Republic of, India, Indonesia, Philippines and Viet Nam, training program will be conducted for 
pension professionals, and briefing seminars will be held for interested parties outside the 
industry. TA implementation will include the establishment of an expert advisory group to guide 
the project and, where possible, will identify suitable local partners in these DMCs, who will be 
particularly important in identifying “thought leaders” in each country. 
 
17.  The TA will generate the following outputs. 
(i)  Customized training materials, including a road map for SRI implementation, 
compilation of case studies and best practice examples, and analysis of social 
and environmental constraints in key DMCs. 
(ii)  Reports  summarizing  each  training  seminar  held  in  the  identified  DMCs, 
including attendance, update on level of awareness, and key themes emerging. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
1.  Major Components 
 
  a.   Analysis of Global Trends and Creation of Asia-Specific Information  
    and Training Tools 
 
18.  This component will consist of the following. 
(i)  Analysis  of  global  trends  in  SRI  and  corporate  governance  relevant  to  the 
pensions  industry,  and  research  into  best  practice  in  the  pensions  industry 
around  the  world.  Research  will  include  meetings  with  pension  industry 
professionals  and  other  parties,  such  as  fund  management  professionals, 
investment advisers, SRI experts, and relevant NGOs. 
(ii)  Examination of the importance of SRI to optimizing fiduciary behavior in the 
pensions industry. 
(iii)  Compilation  of  best  practice  examples  and  case  studies  from  the  pensions 
industry around the world, focusing where possible on Asia-based examples. 
(iv)  Formulation of road map for SRI implementation in the pensions industry in Asia, 
including SRI metrics, performance characteristics, and risks and opportunities 
associated with different SRI implementation strategies.

5
(v)  Examination  of  social  and  environmental  constraints  in  key  DMCs  and  their 
impact on each country’s implementation road map. 
(vi)  Creation of training tools for use with pensions professionals in the DMCs. 
(vii)  Creation  of  customized  information  appropriate  for  discussion  with  other 
interested  parties,  such  as  academics,  fund  management  professionals, 
investment advisers, and NGOs. 
 
b.    Training Programs and Briefing Seminars in Key DMCs 
 
19.  A training program for pension professionals (pensions officers, trustees, and regulators) 
will be carried out in SRI training program for pension professionals (pensions officers, trustees, 
and regulators) in PRC, India, Indonesia, Philippines, Viet Nam. The training program will cover 
the following. 
(i)  Importance  of  governance  and  sustainable  investment  policies  to  optimizing 
fiduciary behavior in the pensions industry. 
(ii)  Global and regional developments in SRI and governance, and examples of best 
practice. 
(iii)  SRI  implementation  road  map,  including  development  of  governance  and 
sustainable  investment  policies,  as  appropriate  for  each  DMC,  and  its 
relationship with that country’s social and environmental constraints.  
(iv)  Technical  and  operational  skills  required  for  execution  of  governance  and 
sustainable investment policies to international standards under the road map, 
including: 
(a)  SRI metrics, performance characteristics, and risk evaluation; 
(b)  fund manager and company engagement; 
(c)  reporting and measurement mechanisms; 
(d)  accountability and communication with pension fund beneficiaries; and 
(e)  collaboration  with  other  pensions  professionals  or  third  parties  on 
governance and SRI issues. 
 
20.  Seminars  will  also  be  organized  in  these  DMCs  for  interested  parties  outside  the 
pensions industry—including government, academics, business groups, and NGOs—to ensure 
that these stakeholders are kept informed and engaged on SRI and governance issues. In 
addition to the content described in paragraph 16, these seminars will pay particular attention to 
the interests of these other groups, for example: 
(i)  multiple stakeholder involvement in pension and social security architecture; 
(ii)  engagement between pension funds, fund mangers, and investee companies; 
and 
(iii)  communication between NGOs and pension funds on social and environmental 
issues. 
 
c.    Public Briefing Event for a Wider Audience  
 
21.  This component of the TA will take the form of a public briefing event, to be scheduled at 
a time and place to be agreed, in order to attract the widest and most relevant audience. The 
intention of the briefing is to draw in world experts, raise awareness in the wider investment 
community  and  NGO  grouping,  and  to  provide  further  momentum  to  the  process  of

6   
communication within the pensions industry. This briefing will update the attendees on issues 
arising from the training programs and briefing seminars, including the following.  
(i)  Importance of SRI and governance issues to optimizing fiduciary behavior in the 
pensions industry in the region, and level of awareness of this link in key DMCs. 
(ii)  Level  of  relevant  technical  and  operational skills  in  the  pensions  industry  in 
identified DMCs, and best practice examples from around the region. 
(iii)  Discussion of road map for SRI implementation (i.e., research and promotion) in 
the  pensions  industry  in  Asia,  and  influence  of  social  and  environmental 
constraints in individual DMCs. 
(iv)  Availability of SRI products and alternative/social investment programs, such as 
microfinance, in the region. 
(v)  Role of professional advisers and third parties on governance and SRI issues. 
(vi)  Interaction  between  NGOs  and  pension  funds  on  social  and  environmental 
issues. 
 
22.  In addition to informing the delegates, this public briefing event is intended to encourage 
dialogue and peer group support—by facilitating communication between pension professionals 
in more developed countries and those in DMCs, as well as SRI experts and NGOs—with the 
aim of fostering skills transfer and collaboration on sustainability and governance issues. The 
participants are expected to make a financial contribution toward their attendance at the event.  
 
23.   The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
24.  The total cost of the TA will be $210,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the 
Government of Switzerland and administered by ADB. The budget (Appendix 2) includes a cost 
recovery component for the briefing seminars and public briefing event. The fee of $35 per 
person is consistent with fees charged for similar briefings in the region. The first component of 
the program—training for public pension officials—does not contain a cost recovery component 
because socially responsible investment is still a very new concept for public pensions in Asian 
developing  countries,  and  it  would  make  it  extremely  difficult  to  reach  the  most  relevant 
professionals if a fee is charged at the early stages of outreach to these public institutions. ADB 
shall not finance any undertaking or activity in the territory of any member country unless and 
until it has received from the government of each member country a letter of no objection or 
concurrence with respect to such undertaking or activity. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
25.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. The Private Sector Operations Department 
(PSOD)  will  be  responsible  for  overall  and  day-to-day  monitoring  of  TA  activities.  The 
Association  for  Sustainable  &  Responsible  Investment  in  Asia  (ASrIA)  will  be  engaged  to 
implement the TA, which consists of 13 person-months of work for research and workshop 
coordination. ASrIA is a not-for-profit, membership association dedicated to promoting corporate 
responsibility and SRI  practices in the Asia and Pacific region. It has a broad reach and 
credibility  in  sustainable  and  responsible  investment  in  Asia  and  is  the  only  not-for-profit 
institution with a regional Asian mandate to promote SRI. Its over 100 members include Asian 
financial and investment institutions; development finance institutions; corporations; and not-for-
profit, academic, community, and government institutions. In addition, ASrIA has strong links 
with Switzerland, which is funding the TA.

7
 
26.  Members include organizations such as Daiwa Securities, Nikko Asset Management, 
Calvert  Group,  Goldman  Sachs,  Henderson  Global  Investors,  Rabobank  International, 
International Finance Corporation, UBS Global Asset Management, Zurich Insurance Group, 
Credit  Suisse,  Bank  Sarasin,  and  Sustainable  Asset  Management  Group.  ADB  became  a 
member of ASrIA in 2004 as part of its regional activities to support SRI.  
 
27.  There are a number of important complementarities between the strategic priorities of 
ADB and the objectives of ASrIA, with focus on: (i) sustainable development, (ii) private sector 
development  that  incorporates  environmental  and  social  safeguards,  (iii)  corporate  social 
responsibility and good governance, and (iv) building greater awareness of the benefits of SRI 
and best practices to enhance project performance and shareholder value. 
 
28.  ASriA  has  experience  in  similar  projects  involving  organizing  and  promotion  of 
conferences,  seminars,  and  workshops  that  provide  a  platform  for  different  sectors  and 
stakeholders to exchange information and perspectives in SRI issues. ASriA also publishes 
wide-ranging research on these and related issues, and runs corporate training programs.   
 
29.  ASrIA’s flagship conference on SRI (held in Hong Kong in 2001, Tokyo in 2002, and 
Singapore in 2004) drew participants from Asia, Australia, Europe, and North America. In 2003, 
ASrIA was invited to run a workshop on SRI and pensions at the United Nations Environment 
Programme Finance Initiative’s Global Roundtable in Tokyo. Workshops on pension funds have 
also been conducted in the Republic of Korea, Singapore, and Thailand; and the association 
has developed a database of pension fund industry contacts focusing on sustainable investment 
practitioners in the pensions industry worldwide. Its 2004 international conference featured a 
pensions  roundtable  including  participants  from  Australia,  the  United  Kingdom,  the  United 
States, and New Zealand. 
 
30.  ADB will directly contract ASrIA to carry out implementation of the RETA in accordance 
with Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (April 2006, as amended from time to time).     
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
31.  The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved 
administering technical assistance not exceeding an amount of the equivalent of $210,000, to 
be financed by the Government of Switzerland on a grant basis, for Capacity Building for 
Sustainable Investment and Governance in the Pensions Industry and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.

(i)  Research and analysis of global trends in socially responsible investment (SRI) 
and corporate governance.  
(a)  Analysis of global trends in SRI and corporate governance relevant to the 
pensions industry. Research will include meetings with pension industry 
professionals and other parties, such as fund management professionals,

organizations (NGOs).   
 
(b)  Examination of the importance of SRI to optimizing fiduciary behavior in 
the pensions industry. 
 
(c)  Compilation  of  best  practice  examples  and  case  studies  from  the 
pensions industry around the world, focusing where possible on Asia-
based examples. 
 
(d)  Formulation of road map for SRI implementation in the pensions industry 
in Asia, including examination of SRI metrics, performance characteristics, 
and risks and opportunities associated with different SRI products and

(e)  Analysis of social and environmental constraints in identified developing 
member countries (DMCs) and their impact on the implementation road 
map. 
 
(ii)  Development of a training program for pensions industry professionals in DMCs. 
(a)  Development  of  training  program  content,  using  the  analysis  and 
feedback from pensions industry practitioners.  
 
(b)  Creation  of  appropriate  Asia-specific  information  and  training  tools, 
including best practice case studies and implementation tools. 
 
(c)  Identification  of  appropriate  senior  pensions  industry  professionals  to 
invite to the training program. 
 
(d)  Ongoing consultation with industry associations and the expert advisory 
group set up to guide the program. 
 
(iii)  Development  of  briefing  seminars  for  other  interested  parties,  including 
government, academics, business groups, and NGOs in DMCs. 
(a)  Development  of  briefing  seminar  content,  and  creation  of  appropriate 
Asia-specific  information  and  training  tools,  using  the  analysis  and 
feedback from pensions industry practitioners.  
 
(b)  Identification of appropriate invitees to the briefing seminars, with the 
intention  of  securing  representation  from  government,  academics, 
business groups, and NGOs.

12    Appendix 3 
 
(iv)  Implementation and organization of the training program and briefing seminars. 
(a)  Reservation of venues for the training program and briefing seminars and 
coordination of related activities, including audiovisual, transportation, and 
interpreting facilities. 
 
(b)  Production of training and seminar materials, including translation where 
required. 
 
(c)  Correspondence  and  communication  with  prospective  training  and 
seminar attendees. 
 
(v)  Development of wider public briefing event.  
(a)  Development of event format and creation of briefing material, drawing on 
the analysis, and the experience of the training program and briefing 
seminars. 
 
(b)  Identification  of  appropriate  invitees  to  the  briefing  event,  with  the 
intention  of  securing  representation  from  government,  academics, 
business groups, investment professionals, advisers, SRI experts, and 
NGOs. 
 
(vi)  Implementation and organization of public briefing event.  
(a)  Reservation  of  venue  and  coordination  of  related  activities,  including 
audiovisual, transportation, and interpreting facilities. 
 
(b)  Production of briefing material, including translation where required. 
 
(c)  Correspondence and communication with prospective attendees. 
 
2.   The following deliverables will be submitted to the Asian Development Bank (ADB).  
 
 
(i)  Progress reports including inception report, midterm report, and final report.  
(ii)  Customized  training  materials,  including  compilation  of  case  studies,  best 
practice examples in sustainable and responsible investment and governance 
practices, and analysis of social and environmental constraints in key DMCs. 
(iii)  Reports summarizing each training seminar and briefing event held in People’s 
Republic of China (PRC), India, Indonesia, Philippines, and Viet Nam DMCs—
including attendance by type, update on level of awareness, and key themes 
emerging.  
(iv)  Report summarizing the public briefing event, including attendance records.
